name: Libraries
body:
There are:
* static libraries (*.a)
* shared libraries (*.so)

A static library is essentialy a set of object files.

### How to create an object file?
```c++
#include <iostream>

using namespace std;

int foo()
{
  cout << "I'm foo()" << endl;
}
```
```
g++ -c tools.cpp
```
Result: tools.o

### How to create a static library?
```
ar -cq libtools.a tools.o
```

And check the results (list the content of a specified archive):
```
$ ar -t libtools.a
tools.o
```

### How to use a library?
```c++
#include <iostream>
#include "tools.h"

using namespace std;

int main()
{
  cout << "I'm calling foo()..." << endl;
  foo();
  cout << "I'm back!" << endl;
}
```
```
g++ -L . main.cpp -ltools
```
It's important to type `-ltools` option after `main.cpp`.
[Here's why.](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7783345/library-is-linked-but-reference-is-undefined)

### How to find all static libraries in your system?
```
find / -name *.a 2>/dev/null
```
